metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: The z-index property specifies the stack order of an element.
content.html: The z-index property specifies the stack order of an element.

content.text: When elements are positioned, they can overlap other elements.
content.html: When elements are positioned, they can overlap other elements.

content.text: The z-index property specifies the stack order of an element (which element should be placed in front of, or behind, the others).
content.html: The z-index property specifies the stack order of an element (which element should be placed in front of, or behind, the others).

content.text: An element can have a positive or negative stack order:
content.html: An element can have a positive or negative stack order:

content.code: This is a heading Because the image has a z-index of -1, it will be placed behind the text.

content.code_html:
img {
  position: absolute;
  left: 0px;
  top: 0px;
  z-index: -1;
}

content.text: Note: z-index only works on positioned elements (position: absolute, position: relative, position: fixed, or position: sticky) and flex items (elements that are direct children of display: flex elements).
content.html: Note: z-index only works on positioned elements (position: absolute, position: relative, position: fixed, or position: sticky) and flex items (elements that are direct children of display: flex elements).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
position: relative;  z-index: 1;  
  border: 2px solid black;  height: 100px;  margin: 30px;

position: absolute;  z-index: 3;  background: lightgray;  height: 60px;   
  width: 70%;  left: 50px;  top: 50px;

content.code:
Black box
 
Gray box
 
Green box

syntax_highlighting.text:
position: relative;  z-index: 1;  
  border: 2px solid black;  height: 100px;  margin: 30px;

position: absolute;  z-index: 3;  background: lightgray;  height: 60px;   
  width: 70%;  left: 50px;  top: 50px;

content.code_html:
<html>
<head>
<style>
.container {
  position: relative;
}

.black-box {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  border: 2px solid black;
  height: 100px;
  margin: 30px;
}

.gray-box {
  position: absolute;
  z-index: 3;
  background: lightgray;
  height: 60px;
  width: 70%;
  left: 50px;
  top: 50px;
}

.green-box {
  position: absolute;
  z-index: 2;
  background: lightgreen;
  width: 35%;
  left: 270px;
  top: -15px;
  height: 100px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="container">
  <div class="black-box">Black box</div>
  <div class="gray-box">Gray box</div>
  <div class="green-box">Green box</div>
</div>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
position: relative;  z-index: 1;  
  border: 2px solid black;  height: 100px;  margin: 30px;

position: absolute;  z-index: 3;  background: lightgray;  height: 60px;   
  width: 70%;  left: 50px;  top: 50px;

content.text: If two positioned elements overlap each other without a z-index specified, the element defined last in the HTML code will be shown on top.
content.html: If two positioned elements overlap each other without a z-index specified, the element defined last in the HTML code will be shown on top.
